contextId.occurrenceNote: Becoming afraid is spoken of as if feat came and attacked them. Alternate translation: "we have become afraid of you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: fear of you has come upon us

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the fearful people to ice melting and flowing away. Possible meanings are 1) they will be weak in the Israelites' presence or 2) they will be scattered. Alternate translation: "will be so afraid that they will not resist you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will melt away before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of the land toward Israel are like a substance that melts in the presence of heat. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: inhabitants of the land are melting away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: "the people will see what I do and realize that I have made you a great man" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will make you a great man in the eyes of all Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will force the other people living on the land to leave or be killed. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: drive out from before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: God spoke of the land being good for animals and plants as if the milk and honey from those animals and plants were flowing through the land. Alternate translation: "a land that is excellent for raising livestock and growing crops" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: a land flowing with milk and honey

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their disgrace is spoken of as if it were a large stone that blocked their path. Here "rolled away" means "removed." Alternate translation: "This day I have removed the disgrace of Egypt from you" or "You were disgraced when you were slaves in Egypt. But, today I have caused you to no longer be disgraced" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This day I have rolled away the disgrace of Egypt from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here looking up is spoken of as if Joshua literally lifted his eyes in his hands. Alternate translation: "he looked up and saw that a man was standing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he lifted up his eyes and looked, and behold, a man was standing

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being careful is spoken of as if they are to guard themselves. "Be careful that you do not take the things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: be on guard about taking the things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Doing something that makes bad things to happen to the city is spoken of as bringing trouble on it. Alternate translation: "you will cause bad things to happen to it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you will bring trouble on it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being cursed in Yahweh's sight represents being cursed by Yahweh. Alternate translation: "May Yahweh curse the man who rebuilds" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Cursed is the man in Yahweh's sight who rebuilds

contextId.occurrenceNote: The consequence of a man laying a new foundation for Jericho is that his firstborn son would die. This is spoken of as if it were a cost that the man would pay. Alternate translation: "If he lays the foundation, he will lose his firstborn son" or "If he lays the foundation, his firstborn son will die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: At the cost of his firstborn son, he will lay the foundation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The consequence of a man setting up new gates for Jericho is that his youngest son would die. This is spoken of as if it were a cost that the man would pay. Alternate translation: "If he sets up its gates, he will lose his youngest son" or "If he sets up it gates, his youngest son will die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: at the cost of his youngest son, he will set up its gates

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Joshua's fame, not Yahweh's. Becoming known among the people throughout the land is spoken of as if his fame spread. Alternate translation: "Joshua became famous throughout the land" or "people throughout the land learned about Joshua" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his fame spread throughout the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: "anger" and "burned" indicates intensity, not that fire is present. Alternate translation: "Yahweh's anger burned like a fire" or "Yahweh was very angry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh's anger burned

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hiding their sin represents trying to keep others from knowing that they have sinned. Alternate translation: "They have stolen those things, and then they tried to keep people from knowing that they sinned" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They have stolen and then also hidden their sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Breaking the covenant represents disobeying it. Alternate translation: "he has disobeyed the covenant of Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he has broken the covenant of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hiding information represents trying to keep someone from knowing it. Alternate translation: "Do not try to prevent me from knowing what you have done" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not hide it from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Turning away his anger represents stopping being angry. Burning anger represents strong anger. Alternate translation: "Yahweh stopped being angry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh turned away his burning anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh enabling Israel to conquer the enemy army and kill all of the soldiers is spoken of as if Yahweh killed the soldiers and then gave them to Israel. Alternate translation: "I will enable Israel to kill all of them in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am giving them all to Israel as dead men

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" represents power. Yahweh enabling the army of Israel to conquer their enemy is spoken of as if Yahweh had put the enemy army into Israel's hand. Alternate translation: "Yahweh enabled Israel to conquer the enemy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh gave the enemy into the hand of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hazor being the most important city is spoken of as Hazor being the head of the other kingdoms. Alternate translation: Hazor had been the most important of all these kingdoms" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.glQuote: Hazor had been head of all these kingdoms

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing the people of the cities to be stubborn is spoken of as if Yahweh had hardened their hearts. Alternate translation: "it was Yahweh who caused them to act stubbornly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: it was Yahweh who hardened their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joshua giving the land to the Israelites is spoken of as if he had given the Israelites an inheritance as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "Joshua gave the land to the Israelites as a permanent possession" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Joshua gave it as an inheritance to Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that Israel will claim is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they will receive as a permanent possession. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: land ... as an inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that Moses assigned to the tribes of Israel is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Moses gave no inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the great honor that the Levites had by serving Yahweh as priests as if the offerings were something that they would inherit. Alternate translation: "The offerings of Yahweh ... are what they will have for their provision" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The offerings of Yahweh ... are their inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that Moses assigned to the tribe of Reuben is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that the tribe of Reuben received as a permanent possession. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of the tribe of Reuben

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that Moses assigned to the tribe of Gad is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that the tribe of Gad received as a permanent possession. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This is the inheritance of the tribe of Gad

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that Moses assigned to the half tribe of Manasseh is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that he gave to them as a permanent possession. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Moses gave an inheritance to the half tribe of Manasseh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that Moses assigned to the tribes of Israel on the east side of the Jordan is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that Moses gave to them as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This is the land that Moses assigned to them as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This is the inheritance that Moses assigned to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the great honor that the Levites had by serving Yahweh as priests as if Yahweh were something that they would inherit. Alternate translation: "Yahweh, the God of Israel, is what they have" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh, the God of Israel, is their inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that the people of Israel acquired is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the areas of land that the people of Israel received as their inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that Moses gave to the tribes is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Moses had given the inheritance of the two and one-half tribes beyond the Jordan, but to the Levites he gave no inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Making the people very afraid is spoken of as if it were making the hearts of the people melt. Alternate translation: "made the people very afraid" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: made the heart of the people melt with fear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being loyal to Yahweh is spoken of as if it were completely following Yahweh. Alternate translation: "I remained loyal to Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I completely followed Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that Caleb and his descendants would have is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they would receive as a permanent possession. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the land ... will be an inheritance for you and for your children forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hebron is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that Caleb received as a permanent possession. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: gave Hebron as an inheritance to Caleb

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being loyal to Yahweh is spoken of as if it were completely following Yahweh. Alternate translation: "he remained loyal to Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he completely followed Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The point at which the river empties into the sea is spoken of as if it were the mouth of the river. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: at the mouth of the Jordan

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that the tribe of Judah received is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This was the land that the tribe of Judah received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of the tribe of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that the tribes of Manasseh and Ephraim possessed is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "received this land as their inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: received their inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that Ephraim possessed is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This was the land that the tribe of Ephraim received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of the tribe of Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that the tribe of Manasseh possessed is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "within the land that the tribe of Manasseh had received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: within the inheritance of the tribe of Manasseh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that the people received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "to give to us some land as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to give to us an inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "received land as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: received an inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that the tribes would receive is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they would receive as a permanent possession. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "to whom Joshua had not assigned land as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: whose inheritance had not been assigned

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that they are to survey is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that each of the tribes would receive as a permanent possession. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their inheritances

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joshua speaks of the great honor that the Levites have by serving Yahweh as priests as if it were something that they inherited. Alternate translation: "for the priesthood of Yahweh is what they have" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for the priesthood of Yahweh is their inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that the tribes received is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "have received land as their inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: have received their inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Land that is in the form of a slope or ridge is spoken of as if it were a shoulder. Alternate translation: "the slope of Beth Arabah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the shoulder of Beth Arabah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Land that is in the form of a slope or ridge is spoken of as if it were a shoulder. Alternate translation: "the north slope of Beth Hoglah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the north shoulder of Beth Hoglah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that the tribe of Benjamin received is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This was the land that the tribe of Benjamin received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of the tribe of Benjamin

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land and cities that the tribe of Benjamin received are spoken of as if they were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This was the land and the cities that the tribe of Benjamin received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of Benjamin

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that the tribes received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "The land that they received as an inheritance was in the middle of the land that the tribe of Judah received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Their inheritance was in the middle of the inheritance that belonged to the tribe of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land and cities that the tribe of Simeon received are spoken of as if they were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "They had the following cities for their inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They had for their inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land and cities that the tribe of Simeon received are spoken of as if they were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This was the land and the cities that the tribe of Simeon received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of the tribe of Simeon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land and cities that the tribe of Zebulun received are spoken of as if they were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This was the land and the cities that the tribe of Zebulun received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of the tribe of Zebulun

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land and cities that the tribe of Issachar received are spoken of as if they were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This was the land and the cities that the tribe of Issachar received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of the tribe of Issachar

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land and cities that the tribe of Asher received are spoken of as if they were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This was the land and the cities that the tribe of Asher received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of the tribe of Asher

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land and cities that the tribe of Naphtali received are spoken of as if they were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This was the land and the cities that the tribe of Naphtali received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of the tribe of Naphtali

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land that the tribe of Dan received is spoken of as if it was an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "The territory of land that the tribe of Dan received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The territory of its inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land and cities that the tribe of Dan received are spoken of as if they were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "This was the land and the cities that the tribe of Dan received as an inheritance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This was the inheritance of the tribe of Dan

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city that Joshua received is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that he received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "gave a city within their own land as an inheritance to Joshua son of Nun" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: gave an inheritance among themselves to Joshua son of Nun

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land and cities that the various tribes received are spoken of as if they were an inheritance that they received as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: "These are the portions of land and the cities ... assigned as inheritances" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: These are the inheritances ... assigned

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person obeying Yahweh is spoken of as if he were walking on Yahweh's ways or roads. Alternate translation: "to obey everything he says" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to walk in all his ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelite tribes who lived across the Jordan River would enter Canaan at the place where they built the altar. This place is spoken of as if it was the "front" or "entrance" to Canaan where the other tribes lived. Alternate translation: "at the entrance to the land of Canaan" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: at the front of the land of Canaan

contextId.occurrenceNote: The altar is spoken of as if it were a witness that could testify to the rights of the three tribes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to be a witness between us and you

contextId.occurrenceNote: To stop following Yahweh is spoken of as if they were turning away from him. Alternate translation: "stop following him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: turn away from following him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The altar is spoken of as if it were a witness that could testify for the three tribes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: It is a witness between us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disobeying the commands of the law of Moses is spoken of as turning to the right or to the left away from a path. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: turning aside from it neither to the right hand nor to the left

contextId.occurrenceNote: "hold tightly to Yahweh." Believing in Yahweh is spoken of as if they were holding tightly onto him. Alternate translation: "continue to believe in Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: cling to Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Accepting the beliefs of these nations is spoken of as holding tightly to them. Alternate translation: "accept the beliefs of the survivors of these nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: cling to the survivors of these nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases speak of the troubles these nations will cause Israel as if they were as painful as whips and thorns. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: whips on your backs and thorns in your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Kindled" here is a metaphor for the beginning of Yahweh's anger, like a fire is "kindled" or started with "kindling" or very easy to start burning like dried grass or small twigs. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will begin to be angry with you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the anger of Yahweh will be kindled against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joshua's summons to the tribes is spoken of as if he gathered them together in a basket. Alternate translation: "Joshua asked all the tribes of Israel to meet with him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Joshua gathered all the tribes of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or desire. Alternate translation: "If you do not want" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: If it seems wrong in your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's anger is spoken of as if he was a fire that would destroy them. Alternate translation: "He will destroy you as with fire" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He will consume you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Deciding to obey Yahweh only is spoken of as turning their heart towards him. Here "heart" represents the whole person. In this case, "heart" is plural because it refers to all the Israelites as a single group. However, it may be best to translate it in the plural since "your" is plural. Alternate translation: "turn yourselves to Yahweh" or "decide to obey Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.glQuote: turn your heart to Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Establishing laws is spoken of as if Joshua physically set them in place like monuments. Alternate translation: "He established decrees and laws" or "He gave them laws and decrees to obey" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He put in place decrees and laws
